pros: In most locations, you will have great coworkers and a fun work environment, you also get free drinks on your shifts, a free coffee or tea mark out every week, and they have great benefit tiers depending on how much you pay into them. Scheduling is done 3 weeks in advance and availability requirements are great for students. You will have many regulars that are very pleasant. It's a great experience to grow overall.
cons:
Despite the pros, there are many cons the biggest one is, you are customers punching bags and for the most part, expected to take it. There's almost always favoritism, being understaffed and expected to work like you aren't is a common issue. If you aren't comfortable working with people watching you constantly then I do not recommend it, and if you can't handle customer complaints because you will get a lot of them no matter what you do, there's always more complaints than compliments. Overall staff, baristas especially, are underpaid as the expectations this job comes with it is not a minimum wage job. 

If you're looking for a company to grow with, this isn't the best choice as it's basically a store manager and that's it, and the rate at which they are replaced is remarkable.

review_title: Great People, Not so great Business
pros: Co-workers are incredible, I made some of the best networking connections and friendships while working for Starbucks. Company does provide decent benefit opportunities to those that take advantage ( a friend of mine earned his entire degree paid for by Starbucks in their online education program) Take advantage of the benefits.
cons: Corporate structure is a mess. There is little room for advancement especially for those who do not fit the idealistic personality or look (I personally wasn't interested in advancement but had many fellow partners who were unjustly passed up for opportunities they diligently worked for and in many cases were assured they had by others who had little to no experience with the company).  For a company so focused on progressiveness and empowerment there is little follow through when it comes to employee recognition or management accountability. The company has shifted over the years to be very "trendy" and numbers driven while forgetting about the individuals on the front lines of the business that are overworked, underappreciated and often times abused by customers anxious over the latest glittery, multi-colored fad beverage.

review_title: My Favorite Job I've Ever Had
pros: One of the reasons I love Starbucks is because of their values. They are a highly inclusive company. Being a member of the LGBTQ+ community, that was a very important factor in determining who I was working for. The pay is more than average for this kind of work. The people here are friendly, considerate, and cooperative. For me, the training experience was easy and thorough. I wake up excited to go back to work. To me, it's also just a fun job, getting to make new drinks every day. Also, the employee discount and the free drinks while on-shift don' hurt.
cons: People call off pretty frequently, but that just means that there's an opportunity for more hours, if you need them. I've also heard other people complain that training isn't thorough enough, but that might depend on the person that trains you.

review_title: Companies Should Practice What They Preach
pros:
- good benefits(health, dental, vision)
- stock, 401k
cons:
- doesn’t care as much about the “little people” at the bottom as their commercials would lead you to believe 
- poorly handles pandemics/high risk employees 
- poorly handles employees experiencing deaths, grief, mental health issues(anxiety, depression, etc.)
-favoritism based off of who you’re friends with outside of work
-concerns and complaints to corporate are disregarded and/or the behavior goes unpunished then the complaining employee(s) will be later punished for complaining to begin with

Instead, a new guy who takes 5 minutes to make a single cup of coffee gets paid the same as you, as well as normally getting the same raises.

pros:
- Awesome and fun people to interact

cons:
- Payment is extremely low. Lower than the warehouse worker hourly rate

- Lots of preparations and cleaning. It's like one person has to do everything during busy hours. So basically, lack of teamwork.
